subject: RE: [junit] What's wrong with using inner classes for tests?
msgSnippet: In summary: It just comes back to basic separation of concerns. Manuel Amago. mailto:mamago@bigfoot.com
messageBody:
In summary:

It just comes back to basic separation of concerns.

Manuel Amago.
mailto:mamago@...


> Adding to the thread already in progress:
>
> Having the testcases in inner classes complicates dependency
> tracking
> and can force unnecessary builds. To some extent, this
> depends on how
> smart the compiler/dependency tracker is. If you have a class
> which is
> reasonably central to your project and you change a separate
> test file,
> then the test file is the only thing that gets rebuilt. If the tests
> are in the java file, then other dependent classes may get
> rebuilt even
> if you are only changing the tests (e.g. adding a new
> testcase). With
> the tests in separate files, I can refactor tests without having to
> rebuild or even touch the code itself. When I am refactoring
> tests, I
> want to be able to recompile/rerun after every tiny change and
> turn-around time is important.
>
> Similarly, version control logs are more clear. I can
> readily separate
> code changes from test changes. Pure refactoring should not change
> tests. Test refactoring or coverage improvement should not
> change code.
> All other changes should touch both.
>
> I find that the hit is even larger for documentation generation than
> for compiling the code. I prefer to have the docs
> automatically update
> after every code change.
